subtitle.Text: Sam's story slash school assignment, called "The Menstrual Cycle: A Novella", is kind of a fan favorite, we've found - a lot of people have enjoyed it a lot.
And it's one of those weird things where it wasn't planned... It was... I just...
Let's see. I had decided that I wanted Sam to have done some homework, and I thought sex-ed homework would be interesting, because sex ed is a weird class in high school to be in,
and so I Google searched for an actual sex-ed assignment, and the assignment is a real sex-ed assignment that is given out in the Pacific Northwest, like Seattle...
I think this is technically from the Seattle school district website, that I got this from.
So I found this thing, which I didn't come up with, that I was kind of presented with,
and I think I had been reading some stuff, about cool female spies in World War II, or saboteurs, that had been part of the French resistance, and stuff like that.
And that's why the history book is next to the sex-ed assignment, the intended implication being that Sam was doing history homework,
and sex-ed homework, and the history unit was on World War II, and so kind of as a fuck-you to all of the annoying assumptions implied by the sex ed assignment,
she wrote this story about a woman in the war who was more interesting than her menstrual cycle, you know, that is a person,
but while fulfilling the requirements of the thing, and it ended up being this really just kind of strange juxtaposition of concepts that ended up saying a lot about Sam, I think.
